parts.title: Proactive vs. Reactive: Taking Control of Your Life
parts.body: Proactive vs. Reactive: In controlling your life, being proactive lets you steer your experiences based on your actions, while being reactive means responding to the environment in a passive manner. Calm individuals are proactive, creating situations that align with their values, while reactive ones blame others or circumstances. To cultivate inner calm, stop complaining and blaming, and take responsibility for your actions and attitudes. This focused flexibility makes change less intimidating and helps you engage actively with life. Avoid "if only" mindsets; instead, focus on what you can do here and now.

parts.title: Steps to Empowerment and Reduced Anxiety
parts.body: In creating mental space, we can step back from blame and complaints to focus on what actions we can take. When we realize what causes our anxiety, we can write it down, acknowledge our feelings, and then explore possible options. Shifting focus to solutions empowers us to become calmer and more proactive. By catching ourselves in passive thoughts like "If only," we can instead explore concrete actions to achieve our desires. By tackling excuses and regrets head-on, they transform into beneficial actions, reducing anxiety. Creating a psychological distance allows us to observe situations objectively, promoting calmness and better control. Practicing this helps us see our thoughts and emotions for what they are, separate from reality, which reduces anxiety and increases agency. Techniques like spatial changes help detach from engrossing situations, providing a clearer perspective. Additionally, using tools like journals or imaginary advice can shift our perspective, making problems seem less dire. These methods enable mental flexibility, allowing us to choose constructive actions aligning with our values, instead of reactive ones driven by anxiety or emotions.

parts.title: Valued Action & Managing Rumination
parts.body: This section explains how committed action is more than just performing tasks, it's valued action that aligns with what truly matters to you. By being guided by your values, your actions become meaningful. For instance, when dealing with a cancer diagnosis, staying informed rather than being led by fear is a proactive choice that reflects responsibility for your health. Such actions signify empowerment, as they stem from clear values over external control. Furthermore, the section touches on combating rumination—when you overthink without solving problems. Unlike helpful, problem-solving thinking, rumination causes distress without benefit. To manage this, recognize it doesn’t help and aim to shift your focus to valuable actions instead. This is part of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), where after acknowledging a thought, you decide if it aligns with your values before taking action.

parts.title: Reframing Automatic Negative Thoughts
parts.body: Reframing automatic negative thoughts is about shifting perspective and creating choice by bringing consciousness to what is unconscious. It's important not to judge our thoughts but to shine awareness on them. Automatic negative thoughts can run our lives without us even knowing, forming the basis of how we see ourselves and the world. Rather than focusing on challenging these thoughts as right or wrong, the aim is to understand their impact and find alternative, useful thoughts.

parts.title: Understanding and Overcoming Judgment
parts.body: Judgment, whether directed at ourselves or others, comes from comparing reality with what we think it "should" be. It arises from non-acceptance and creates anxiety. Without awareness, we often relate to our stories of past judgments rather than the moment. Understanding ourselves and others without judgment is a path to calmness and acceptance and makes us more compassionate. Letting go of judgment changes our focus, allowing us to appreciate reality as it is rather than as it "should be," fostering more positive internal and external interactions.

parts.title: Embracing Non-Duality
parts.body:
Embracing Non-Duality

Our tendency to judge ourselves and others can lead to anxiety and dissatisfaction. This comes from splitting reality into good and bad, which is an illusion. Non-duality teaches that opposites are in relation, not conflict. Recognize that life is whole; by dropping judgments, we appreciate differences without anger. Acceptance of our present feelings, even our resistance to those feelings, fosters peace. A helpful practice is to observe situations and people and attribute their qualities to ourselves. This dissolves judgment and emphasizes shared humanity. By using inclusive language like "and" instead of divisive words like "but," we embrace both qualities without conflict. This approach lessens tension, anxiety, and promotes self-acceptance by seeing everyone, including ourselves, as interconnected parts of a larger story.
